subject: monitor: Add up/down count fault detection
commitMessage:
monitor: Add up/down count fault detection

Create an up/down count fault determination algorithm that
could be used in place of the current timer based outOfRange()
function.
The up/down count is a different method for determining when
a fan is faulted by counting up each iteration a rotor is
out of spec and removing those counts when the rotor
returns within spec.

Tested:
    1. Remove a fan and run Mihawk, the counter add 1 when sensor
       is out of spec, and replaced the fan back before hit the
       threshold, the counter decrement back to 0.
    2. Remove a fan, counter add 1 and mark the removed fan as
       nonfunctional when counter reaches the threshold, and
       Replaced the fan back, counter will decrement back to 0
       and fan back to functional.

Change-Id: I632dd2c7553b007beb7ae6bb694a590d2cfc2a1c
Signed-off-by: Jolie Ku <jolie_ku@wistron.com>
Signed-off-by: Matthew Barth <msbarth@us.ibm.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 69f2f48eb6708c7318e47f287fea1b28d9ec9ba7 by Matthew Barth
"Create an up/down count fault determination algorithm that could be used in place of the current timer based outOfRange() function."
Done
remove
Done

remove

There's really not set period of time when using the up/down count method as the count is either being incremented to a threshold(each time the rotor is out of spec) or decremented back to 0(each time the rotor is in spec).
Done

Did you happen to also check that a fan is not marked nonfunctional after removing and then replacing it before the threshold is hit?

Also, does a nonfunctional fan return to functional after its replaced?
update the test, done

We should probably add the available methods here, something like:
`method: [time|count]`
done, named time will cause build error, it will be recognized a type, so I define it as timebased.

Then maybe include a description of each one under here similar to how the sensor_trust_groups list the available classes below.

i.e.)

Available methods:
 * time - ...
 * count - ...
done, named time will cause build error, it will be recognized a type, so I define it as timebased.
Lets update this to add another fan that's monitored by the `count` method
Done, add an example for `count` method

I think you mean "time"

Both the current time duration based and the new count methods use a deviation calculation to determine when a fan's rotor is out of spec. As you see above this, there's a "deviation:" config attribute which both the current time and count methods will need.
Done
This check should be outside the switch statement since there's no reason to run the switch statement if the sensor is out of range and already nonfunctional.
Done

For the `count` mode, this timer should not be started since a fan is determined to be nonfunctional based on if the counter >= the threshold...in fact, the nonfunc timer value will not be configured when using the `count` method
Done

`count` method has no need for a timer, should be able to just call timerExpired(sensor) here. I know calling that function directly seems odd, so it could be updated to be called "updateState(sensor)"
I think it makes sense to call "setFunctional(sensor)"?

Well, that implies its only setting the fan(and sensor) to a being functional, but the current timerExpried(sensor) method handles updating the functional state(functional & nonfunctional) of the fan object in addition to the sensor. That's why my first thought was to update the method name from timerExpired(sensor) to "updateState(sensor)"
Done
Done
This is not required when the method for "count" is given.
Does that mean it should be put in SensorDefinition like `threshold`?

No. I'm just saying that if a user configures the `method` to be "count", this is no longer required to be entered in the configuration. So if `method` is set to "count" then `allowed_out_of_range_time` is not required to be given in the configuration, right? because its not used when the method is the up/down counter?

but I have no idea how to modify it? it seems cannot be removed directly because method "time" need use it.
My thought is move it to SensorDefinition like "threshold" because threshold is used for "count" only.

Moving it to be within the SensorDefinition would not change the fact that its not required to be given in the config when the method is "count" though. The change I'm requesting is right here dealing with the parsing of the YAML configuration (and should also be handled in the parsing of a JSON configuration). Basically more logic needs to be put in here to say:

if 'method' == "time" require/read 'allowed_out_of_range_time' from the YAML, else you can default it to some value (like 0) and it'll just be ignored anyway while fan monitor is running since they chose 'method' == "count".

The key is that 'allowed_out_of_range_time' is required when the 'method' == "time" and needs to stay that way.

Something similar would need to be done for parsing a JSON config.
Done
Why is the threshold being defaulted to 2 when not given? Seems like this could be defaulted to a 1 (i.e. 1 count against a fan deems it nonfunctional)?

it is a retry mechanism, maybe there is an error in the first reading.
I can change to 1 if you think this is no need?

That sounds as though it would be up to the user writing the configuration then to provide a threshold value to handle an error on the first read that they would not immediately cause the fan to be marked nonfunctional.

I think 1 is a better default if the user doesnt provide a `threshold` entry.
Done
count
time
Done
named time will cause build error, it will be recognized a type, so I define it as timebased.
time based functional determination
Done
time
named time will cause build error, it will be recognized a type, so I define it as timebased.
An error should be logged and exception thrown if the configured method that a user provides isnt supported.
Done
This is not required when the method is "count"
Done
This timer delay is unnecessary
Done
When the count is `false`, the counter should be decremented back to 0. The counter on a sensor increments up to a threshold amount or decrements back down to 0.
Done
There's no need for a timer on the `count` method. The timer used in hwmon that sends the propertiesChanged signals for the tach will be the iteration the counter is on.
Done
time
Done
Lets split this into a `setCounter(bool count)` method and a `getCounter()` method
Done
Did you happen to also check that a fan is not marked nonfunctional after removing and then replacing it before the threshold is hit?
update the test, done

These can just be directly set to the timebased method for the default.

size_t method = MethodMode::timebased;
Done
The method is not required, the error is simply an unsupported method was given in the json config.
Done
Done

This should decrement back to 0, not immediately go back to 0 upon the first iteration the fan is seen functional again. See my prior comment on this:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/#/c/openbmc/phosphor-fan-presence/+/37559/5..13/monitor/tach_sensor.cpp
Done
inline size_t getCounter () const
Done
This should be within the method check, see my prior comment.
Done
